sentences.text: General elections were held in Liechtenstein on 9 February 2025 to elect the 25 members of the Landtag of Liechtenstein|Landtag. The Patriotic Union (Liechtenstein)|Patriotic Union (VU) won 10 seats, while the Progressive Citizens' Party (FBP) won seven, the lowest in its history. The Democrats for Liechtenstein (DpL) won six seats, being the highest amount of seats won by a third party in Liechtenstein's history. The Free List (Liechtenstein)|Free List (FL) won two seats. Voter turnout was 76.3%.

references.text: <ref name=":3">{{Cite web |title=Landtagswahlen 2025 - Ergebnisse |url=https://www.landtagswahlen.li/resultat/16 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250211170451/https://www.landtagswahlen.li/resultat/16 |archive-date=2025-02-11 |access-date=2025-02-09 |website=www.landtagswahlen.li |language=de}}</ref>

sentences.text: Following the election, the VU and FBP entered into a renewed coalition government, and the Brigitte Haas cabinet|new government was sworn in on 10 April 2025. Haas is the first female prime minister in Liechtenstein's history.

references.text: <ref name=":7">{{Cite news |date=4 April 2025 |title=FBP- und VU-Vorstandsgremien genehmigen Koalitionsvertrag |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/fbp-und-vu-vorstandsgremien-genehmigen-koalitionsvertrag-art-595131 |access-date=4 April 2025 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=10 April 2025 |title=Neue Regierung ist im Amt |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/neue-regierung-ist-im-amt-art-595778 |access-date=10 April 2025 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de}}</ref>

<ref name=":4">{{Cite news |date=10 February 2025 |title=The tiny Alpine principality of Liechtenstein is set to get its first female prime minister |url=https://apnews.com/article/liechtenstein-first-female-prime-minister-haas-3e6b8510cb9f1e61f3692440848966d1 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250211215945/https://apnews.com/article/liechtenstein-first-female-prime-minister-haas-3e6b8510cb9f1e61f3692440848966d1 |archive-date=11 February 2025 |access-date=10 February 2025 |work=Associated Press}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{Main|2021 Liechtenstein general election}}
In the 2021 Liechtenstein general election, the Patriotic Union (Liechtenstein)|Patriotic Union (VU) and Progressive Citizens' Party|Progressive Citizens' Party (FBP) each won ten seats. As a result, the two parties formed a coalition government, ultimately under Daniel Risch of the VU. The Free List (Liechtenstein)|Free List and Democrats for Liechtenstein won three and two seats in 2021 respectively. A new political party, Mensch im Mittelpunkt, was formed in 2022.

references.text: <ref name="en8-2-212">{{cite news |date=8 February 2021 |title=Liechtenstein election: Just 23 ballots separate two biggest parties |url=https://www.euronews.com/2021/02/08/liechtenstein-election-just-23-ballots-separate-two-biggest-parties-that-will-now-form-coa |access-date=9 February 2021 |work=Euronews |archive-date=14 February 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210214172314/https://www.euronews.com/2021/02/08/liechtenstein-election-just-23-ballots-separate-two-biggest-parties-that-will-now-form-coa |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{Main|Elections in Liechtenstein}}
The 25 members of the Landtag of Liechtenstein|Landtag are elected by open list proportional representation from two constituencies, Oberland (electoral district)|Oberland with 15 seats and Unterland (electoral district)|Unterland with 10 seats. Voters vote for a Party-list proportional representation|party list and then may strike through candidates for whom they do not wish to cast a preferential vote, and may add names of candidates from other lists. The electoral threshold to win a seat is 8%. Landtag members sit for a four-year term. Voting is compulsory by law and most is carried out by post. Polling stations are open only for one and a half hours on election day. Citizens over 18 years of age who have been resident in the country for one month prior to election day are eligible to vote.<ref name="osce" />

references.text: <ref name="osce">{{cite web |title=Principality of Liechtenstein: Parliamentary Elections 7 February 2021 |url=https://www.osce.org/files/f/documents/a/f/473469.pdf |access-date=9 February 2021 |website=Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights |publisher=OSCE |archive-date=30 January 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210130185505/https://www.osce.org/files/f/documents/a/f/473469.pdf |url-status=live}}</ref>
<ref>[https://archive.today/20130221002007/https://www.gesetze.li/get_lgbl_from_menue_if.jsp?LGBlm=1973050%23art:55 Article 55 (1) of the Volksrechtegesetz (Law of People's Rights)] Gesetze.li</ref>

<ref name="osce" /> Once formed, the Landtag elects the prime minister and four government councillors who govern in a List of cabinets of Liechtenstein|cabinet.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web |last=Vogt |first=Paul |author-link=Paul Vogt (historian) |date=31 December 2011 |title=Regierung |url=https://historisches-lexikon.li/Regierung |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230721135630/https://historisches-lexikon.li/Regierung |archive-date=21 July 2023 |access-date=13 January 2025 |website=Historisches Lexikon des Fürstentums Liechtenstein |language=de}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 25 February 2024, Liechtenstein voters were asked in 2024 Liechtenstein referendums#25 February 2024|a referendum if members of government should be directly elected, a proposal that would have affected the 2025 general election if successful. However, the proposal was rejected by voters.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |title=Abstimmung über das Initiativbegehren "Einbezug des Volkes bei der Bestellung der Regierung" am 25. Februar 2024 |url=https://www.llv.li/de/medienmitteilungen/abstimmung-ueber-das-initiativbegehren-einbezug-des-volkes-bei-der-bestellung-der-regierung-am-25-februar-2024 |access-date=2023-12-31 |website=www.llv.li |language=de |archive-date=2024-01-26 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240126150601/https://www.llv.li/de/medienmitteilungen/abstimmung-ueber-das-initiativbegehren-einbezug-des-volkes-bei-der-bestellung-der-regierung-am-25-februar-2024 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: On 19 February 2024, Daniel Risch declared his intention to not run for re-election. The VU nominated Brigitte Haas for prime minister, being the second woman nominated for the position, behind Sabine Monauni in 2021. The party also nominated Hubert Büchel and Emanuel Schädler as government candidates. Haas stated that she was "available" for multiple terms if elected.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=19 February 2024 |title=Alle drei VU-Regierungsräte kandidieren 2025 nicht mehr |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/aus-diesen-gruenden-tritt-das-bisherige-vu-regierungsteam-2025-nicht-mehr-an-art-557856 |access-date=19 February 2024 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de |archive-date=19 February 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240219195603/https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/aus-diesen-gruenden-tritt-das-bisherige-vu-regierungsteam-2025-nicht-mehr-an-art-557856 |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 13 August 2024, the Progressive Citizens' Party nominated former List of presidents of the Landtag of Liechtenstein|President of the Landtag and foreign minister, Ernst Walch for prime minister. The party also nominated incumbent Deputy Prime Minister of Liechtenstein Sabine Monauni and then party president Daniel Oehry as government candidates. At 68 years old, Walch is the oldest candidate in Liechtenstein's history. He declared his intention to only serve one term as prime minister should he have been elected. In an interview with 1 FL TV, incumbent President of the Landtag, Albert Frick (politician)|Albert Frick, belonging to the FBP, announced that he would not be running for re-election. According to an October 2024 survey, only 48% of respondents wanted a government that included Walch, being the lowest of any candidate.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=13 August 2024 |title=Ernst Walch tritt als Regierungschef für die FBP an |url=https://www.fbp.li/aktuelles/ernst-walch-tritt-als-regierungschef-fuer-die-fbp-an |access-date=13 August 2024 |website=Progressive Citizens' Party|FBP Liechtenstein |language=de |archive-date=13 August 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240813224439/https://www.fbp.li/aktuelles/ernst-walch-tritt-als-regierungschef-fuer-die-fbp-an |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 29 January 2025, the newspaper ''Die Zeit'' published an article regarding Walch. In the article, it criticized his activities as a trustee and his actions as foreign minister, highlighting his involvement in numerous scandals from that time, stating that "Liechtenstein's dark past will catch up with it".

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Kaufmann |first=Gary |date=4 February 2025 |title=Ausländische Medien beobachten FBP-Regierungschefkandidaten |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/aeuslaendische-medien-beobachten-fbp-regierungschefkandidaten-art-589234 |access-date=27 February 2025 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |last=Rohner |first=Markus |date=29 January 2025 |title=Darauf einen Bacardi Cola! |url=https://www.zeit.de/2025/05/liechtenstein-volksparteien-mehrheit-usa-ernst-walch |access-date=27 February 2025 |work=Die Zeit |language=de}}</ref>

sentences.text: In February 2024, the newspaper ''Liechtensteiner Vaterland'' conducted a survey which suggested that only 25% of respondents would support another coalition government between the Patriotic Union and Progressive Citizens' Party. However, the FBP declared that it was open to the formation of a coalition should it have won the election. Brigitte Hass also stated that she was open to a formation of a coalition with the FBP, but was sceptical of other parties.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Sele |first=David |date=28 February 2024 |title=Nur 25 Prozent wollen eine Grosse Koalition aus FBP und VU |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/nur-25-prozent-wollen-eine-grosse-koalition-aus-fbp-und-vu-art-558668 |url-access=subscription |access-date=26 April 2024 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de |archive-date=26 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240426200357/https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/nur-25-prozent-wollen-eine-grosse-koalition-aus-fbp-und-vu-art-558668 |url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |last=Sele |first=David |date=15 October 2024 |title=Wahlen 2025: FBP zeigt sich offen für andere Koalitionspartner |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/wahlen-2025-fbp-zeigt-sich-offen-fuer-andere-koalitionspartner-art-579405 |access-date=23 October 2024 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de |archive-date=9 December 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241209054324/https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/wahlen-2025-fbp-zeigt-sich-offen-fuer-andere-koalitionspartner-art-579405 |url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=3 November 2024 |title=VU-Chefkandidatin Haas ist für Grosse Koalition |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/vu-chefkandidatin-haas-ist-fuer-grosse-koalition-art-580698 |access-date=4 November 2024 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de}}</ref>

sentences.text: The Democrats for Liechtenstein nominated Thomas Rehak and Erich Hasler for government positions on 16 December 2024, being the first time the party has presented government candidates since its formation in 2018. They said that they were open to a coalition with other parties. During campaigning, Rehak suggested the possibility of a three-party coalition, stating that the DpL "had a right to a seat in government". According to polling, the party was predicted to receive a significantly increased share of the vote compared to 2021, perhaps as high as 20%.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=16 December 2024 |title=DpL nominieren Rehak und Hasler als Regierungskandidaten |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/dpl-nominiert-rehak-und-hasler-als-regierungskandidaten-art-584958 |access-date=17 December 2024 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de |archive-date=19 December 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241219151341/https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/dpl-nominiert-rehak-und-hasler-als-regierungskandidaten-art-584958 |url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name="Thöny">{{Cite news |last=Thöny |first=Sina |date=17 February 2025 |title=Wahlumfrage zeigt: Grosse Koalition erhält am meisten Zustimmung |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/wahlumfrage-zeigt-grosse-koalition-erhaelt-am-meisten-zustimmung-art-590023 |access-date=17 February 2025 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de}}</ref>

<ref name=":1">{{Cite news |last=Sele |first=David |date=3 July 2024 |title=Trend: VU und FBP stürzen ab, DpL auf 23 Prozent |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/trend-vu-und-fbp-stuerzen-ab-dpl-auf-23-prozent-art-570226 |url-access=subscription |access-date=28 July 2024 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de |archive-date=8 July 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240708204536/https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/trend-vu-und-fbp-stuerzen-ab-dpl-auf-23-prozent-art-570226 |url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name=":2">{{Cite news |last=Sele |first=David |date=16 December 2024 |title=Trend: Kopf-an-Kopf-Rennen zwischen VU und FBP setzt sich fort |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/trend-kopf-an-kopf-rennen-zwischen-vu-und-fbp-setzt-sich-fort-art-584894 |access-date=16 December 2024 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de |archive-date=19 December 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241219144213/https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/trend-kopf-an-kopf-rennen-zwischen-vu-und-fbp-setzt-sich-fort-art-584894 |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: The Free List did not present any government candidates, but it also stated that it did not rule out participation in government. Mensch Im Mittelpunkt renounced any candidates in December 2024. The Independents (Liechtenstein)|The Independents, which had suffered a large electoral defeat in 2021, did not present any candidates.

|Liechtensteiner Vaterland|Vaterland<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=Goop |first=Dunja |date=13 July 2023 |title=Thomas Milic zu DpL-Umfragehoch: «Das wäre ein Jahrhundertergebnis» |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/thomas-milic-zu-dpl-umfragehoch-das-waere-ein-jahrhundertergebnis-art-538000 |access-date=28 July 2024 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de |archive-date=8 July 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240708202433/https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/thomas-milic-zu-dpl-umfragehoch-das-waere-ein-jahrhundertergebnis-art-538000 |url-status=live }}</ref>

sentences.text: The VU received 38.3% of the vote, a 2.7% increase from their 2021 performance and maintained its ten seats in the Landtag. The FBP received 27.5% of the vote, an 8.4% decrease from 2021, and won seven seats, a decrease of three. It is the lowest result in the FBP's history.

references.text: <ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /> The DpL saw its vote share rise 11.1% to 23.3% from 2021 and won six seats, an increase of four, the highest of any third party in Liechtenstein's history. The Free List received 10.9% of the vote, a decrease of 2% from 2021, and won two seats, a decrease of one.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite web |title=Landtagswahlen 2021 - Ergebnisse |url=https://www.landtagswahlen.li/resultat/12 |access-date=2025-02-10 |website=www.landtagswahlen.li |archive-date=2021-02-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210207164649/https://www.landtagswahlen.li/resultat/12 |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: Following the election, the VU invited the FBP to begin negotiations for a renewed coalition government, which the FBP accepted. The session in the Landtag to elect the new government was initially scheduled for 20 March, but was postponed to 10 April. The VU and FBP have agreed to enter into a renewed coalition government.<ref name=":7" /> The DpL also expressed its desire to open negotiations for a coalition government.<ref name="Thöny"/>

references.text: <ref name=":5">{{Cite news |last=Sele |first=David |date=11 February 2025 |title=VU will Regierungskoalition bis Ende März besiegeln |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/vu-will-regierungskoalition-bis-ende-maerz-besiegeln-art-589840 |access-date=11 February 2025 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |last=Sele |first=David |date=20 February 2025 |title=FBP nimmt Einladung der VU zum Sondierungsgespräch an |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/fbp-nimmt-einladung-der-vu-an-art-590756 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de}}</ref>

<ref name=":6">{{Cite news |last=Schädler |first=Patrik |date=13 March 2025 |title=Landtagseröffnung auf 10. April verschoben |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/landtagseroeffnung-auf-10-april-verschoben-art-592830 |access-date=14 March 2025 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de}}</ref>

sentences.text: According to a poll by the Liechtenstein Institute published after the election, 17% and of voters who voted for the FBP in 2021 switched to the VU in 2025. 91% of respondents cited that the choice of Walch as the candidate for prime minister or the FBP's government team in general was the reason for their change in vote. In addition, the same poll suggested that the FBP lost a further 14% of its voting share from 2021 to the DpL, with the majority of respondents citing differing policies for the change.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Sele |first=David |date=12 February 2025 |title=Die FBP verlor laut Umfrage mehr Stimmen an die VU als an die DpL |url=https://www.vaterland.li/liechtenstein/politik/wahlumfrage-zeigt-grosse-koalition-erhaelt-am-meisten-zustimmung-art-590023 |access-date=17 February 2025 |work=Liechtensteiner Vaterland |language=de}}</ref>
